title: 114_s1600
content: The Act titled "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. Exclusive remedies under this section are limited to designated Federal agencies or components. The Privacy Act extends remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing civil actions against agencies for intentional disclosures. Covered persons have the same rights and limitations as individuals under section 552a of title 5, US Code. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" with the concurrence of other officials. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if they have privacy protections in place or have effectively shared information with the United States for preventing criminal offenses. The Attorney General can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if they are not complying with the agreement or no longer meet the requirements for designation. The Attorney General can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if they no longer meet the requirements for designation or impede the transfer of information to the United States by a private entity. The Attorney General determines which agencies are "designated Federal agencies" for this purpose, with limitations on designating agencies outside the Department of Justice without concurrence. The Attorney General can designate an agency as a "designated Federal agency or component" for exchanging information with a covered country, with limitations on designating agencies outside the Department of Justice without concurrence. The Attorney General can designate agencies for information exchange with a "covered country" in the interest of law enforcement. Determinations made are published and not subject to review. The US District Court in DC has exclusive jurisdiction over related claims. Definitions include "agency" and "covered country." The term "covered country" refers to a designated country or organization for information exchange. A "covered person" is a non-individual citizen of a covered country. A "covered record" has the same meaning as a record under US Code once transferred by a public authority or private entity from a covered country. The term "individual" is defined in section 552a(a)(2) of title 5, US Code. This section does not waive privileges or require disclosure of classified information. Upon request, the district court will preserve privileges. The Act does not waive privileges or require disclosure of classified information. The district court will review agency submissions in camera and ex parte. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
